predicted_summary.wugwATSS-billsum(on-un: (This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on December 16, 2006. The summary of that version is repeated here.) (Sec. 3) Directs the Secretary of the Treasury, acting through the Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), to establish a commission to: (1) review the current state and national catastrophe risk management systems; (2) develop a plan to ensure that future catastrophic events are adequately prepared; and (3) report recommendations to Congress. Requires the Commission to report to Congress within 90 days after the enactment of this Act on the state of such systems and plan.Disaster Insurance Reform Act of 2010 - Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to establish a National Commission to study and report to Congress on the management of catastrophic disaster risk in the United States and the need for federal laws to address such management. Requires the Commission to: (1) develop recommendations for a national catastrophe insurance plan; (2) study the structure and function of the private sector property insurance and reinsurance markets; (3) assess the risks of catastrophic risk; (4) evaluate the effectiveness of existing federal programs to protect against catastrophic losses; (5) recommend ways to encourage private sector efforts to address the risk of catastrophic events; (6) recommend a plan to establish an national catastrophic reinsurance fund; and (7) report its findings and recommendations to Congress.(Sec. 3) Directs the Commission to study and report to Congress and the President on: (1) the feasibility and cost of creating a national catastrophic disaster insurance program; and (2) whether such a program should be available to states and individuals to protect against catastrophic losses.(Sec. 5) Directs the Commission to: (1) assess the condition of the property and casualty insurance industry; (2) report to Congress with recommendations and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions to address the conditions of the industry, including proposed regulations; and (3) submit to Congress a final report within 90 days after enactment of this Act.Directs the Commission to consider: (1) the impact on the domestic and international financial markets of insured events; and (2) recommendations for legislative and regulatory changes to improve the availability and competitiveness of such markets.Directs the Secretary of the Treasury, acting through the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), to: (1) study and report to Congress on the feasibility and feasibility of implementing a national catastrophe pool or regional catastrophe pools; (2) provide assistance to states and communities in order to promote risk reduction and increase insurance capacity in such pools; and (3) conduct a study of the potential for implementing a catastrophic insurance system under the Federal Deposit Insurance Act.Authorizes the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to enter into agreements with the Secretary of the Treasury to carry out this Act's purposes.<n> Authorizes appropriations to the Secretary for FY2011-FY2012.Directs the Commission to: (1) take such testimony, receive it, and administer such oaths or affirmations as it considers advisable; and (2) require, by subpoena or otherwise, the attendance and testimony of such witnesses and the production of such evidence. Specifies that: (1) such subpoenas shall bear the signature of the chairperson; (2) enforcement shall be performed by the chairperson or other designated person; and (3) in the case of contumacy or failure to obey a subpoena, the court shall direct the subpoenaed person to appear at any designated place to testify or produce evidence.Exempts information obtained under a subpoena from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) as well as certain administrative or judicial review requirements. Provides that the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) shall not be required to disclose any of the data collected under this Act. Authorizes the FTC to secure directly from any Federal department or agency any official of the United States or a foreign country with the knowledge that such agency may use the data to conduct an investigation or to prepare a regulatory or legislative report.Federal Postal Commission Act of 1995 - Establishes the Federal Commission on Federal Postal Policy to carry out the functions of the Postal Commission. Authorizes the Commission to use the United States mails and other Federal services to conduct its activities. Sets forth administrative support services requirements.Commission Act of 1994 - Establishes a Federal commission to: (1) serve without compensation all members of the commission who are U.S. officers or employees; (2) allow travel expenses, including per diem in lieu of subsistence, at rates authorized for federal employees while away from their homes or regular places of business; (3) establish subcommittees and appoint persons to carry out duties; and (4) appoint and fix the pay of such additional personnel as the commission chairperson considers appropriate.Requires the Commission to submit its final report to the President and the Congress within 60 days of its first meeting. Authorizes appropriations. Directs the Secretary of Labor, acting through the Office of Personnel Management, to submit to the Commission a final report on pay rates for Federal employees, including agency employees, within 30 days after receiving the Commission's final report.
predicted_summary.wugNATSS-billsum(on-un: Commission on catastrophic disaster risk and insurance Act of 2006 - Establishes the Commission to investigate: (1) the availability and affordability of insurance coverage for all types of disasters; (2) the impact on the private sector of insured losses and insured losses; and (3) the ability of states and communities to prepare for and respond to disasters.Establishes a bipartisan commission on catastrophic disaster risk and insurance to study and report to Congress on: (1) the current state and future state of the domestic catastrophic insurance market; (2) how it can be improved to prevent or respond to future catastrophic losses; (3) the future role of the private sector; (4) innovations and reforms necessary to ensure that American consumers have adequate insurance coverage to protect against catastrophic risks; and (5) recommendations to establish a national catastrophic risk insurance fund.Requires the Commission to submit: (1) a preliminary report to the President and Congress; and (2) a final report within 90 days after the enactment of this Act.Provides for the appointment of Commission members by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Senate. Directs the Commission to assess the condition of the property and casualty and to report to Congress.(Sec. 6) Directs the Commission to consider: (1) the catastrophic insurance and reinsurance market structures and the relevant commercial practices in such insurance industries in providing insurance protection; and (2) the best possible range of insurance products at competitive prices. Requires the Commission, in developing a final report, to consider any recommendations for legislation or administrative action that it considers appropriate.(Sec. 3) Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to submit to Congress a report that includes: (1) an analysis of the impact of the federal government's actions on the insurance and reinsurance markets; (2) a detailed analysis of each of the three major catastrophe risk pools established by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC) to serve the insurance industry; (3) a list of the most recent studies on risk management and the implementation of a catastrophic insurance system; (4) an assessment of the potential for a national catastrophe pool or regional catastrophe pools; and (5) a review of the feasibility and feasibility of creating an insurance-based public insurance scheme (in the form of a public insurance plan) for low-income communities.Authorizes the Commission to issue a final report to Congress and to enter into negotiations with the National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC) on the establishment of a federal catastrophe fund to act as a backup to state and local government catastrophe funds.Directs the court to enter into an agreement between the Commission and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) regarding the issuance of subpoenas. Declares that information obtained under a subpoena shall be exempt from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act and shall not be published or disclosed unless the Commission determines that the withholding of such information is contrary to the interest of the United States.Authorizes the Commission to: (1) obtain official data; (2) use Federal mails in the same manner and under the same conditions as other Federal agencies; and (3) obtain administrative support services from U.S. agencies.(Sec. 8) Sets forth the commission's personnel procedures.<n>(Sec. 9) Directs the Commission to adopt internal regulations governing the receipt of gifts or donations of services or property, similar to regulations governing Federal employees' travel expenses.<n> (Sec 10) Authorizes appropriations.Authorizes the Commission to appoint additional personnel without regard to Federal civil service law and to make additional personnel available for Commission activities. Authorizes appropriations. Directs the Government Accountability Office to report to the Commission annually on Commission activities, including an assessment of the Commission's effectiveness in achieving its goals and recommendations.Requires the Commission to terminate 60 days after it submits its final report. Authorizes appropriations, with specified amounts designated for the General Services Administration and the Department of Commerce.

predicted_summary.wugwATSS-billsum(on-un: Empowerment of iraqi women Act of 2006 - States that it is the policy of the United States to: (1) support the political empowerment of iraq's women; (2) support the development of a national constitution for the people of i Iraq; (3) provide assistance to Iraq to promote human rights and democratic institutions and organizations, including the participation of women in the political process; and (4) ensure that women are included as members of the national legislature, the national government, and local governments in the reconstruction of Iraq.Requires the Administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) to establish a fund to assist women and girls in iraq in the areas of political, legal and human rights, health care, education, training, security, and shelter. Authorizes the use of such funds to support: (1) direct financial and programmatic assistance to the iraq ministry of women's affairs to promote its strengthening as the government of iraq continues its transition to a long-term government structure and to ensure the participation of iraqi women in the political, economic, and social development of their country; (2) technical assistance to iraq ministries for the implementation of programs to improve the quality and capacity of women, especially those who are members of the armed forces; and (3) financial assistance to Iraq to support its government in the development and implementation of policies to promote the empowerment of women and the rights of women to participate in the government and the development of Iraq.Directs the Administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) to report annually to Congress regarding such agency's activities in Iraq and Afghanistan, including regarding: (1) women-centered economic development programs; (2) health programs, including programs to prevent trafficking in persons and domestic violence; (3) education programs to promote the education of iraqi girls beyond primary school; and (4) women's educational facilities.Requires specified percentages of such assistance to be made available directly to iraqi-led local nongovernmental organizations, including at least 5% in FY2010 and each subsequent fiscal year to support their programmatic activities and organizational development.Declares that such assistance shall not be construed to affect the rights of Iraqi women to: (1) self-organization, (2) private sector investment, or (3) political participation. Authorizes appropriations for FY2013-FY2018 for such assistance.Requires the President to report annually to Congress on U.S. activities to guarantee the rights of iraqi women in Iraq. Requires the Secretary of State to include such information in the annual report. Directs the President, within 60 days after enactment of this Act and annually thereafter, to transmit to Congress a report containing documentation of the activities of the United States to guarantee such rights.
predicted_summary.wugNATSS-billsum(on-un: Empowerment of iraqi women Act of 2006 - Directs the Secretary of State to report to Congress on the status of women's human rights in iraq and implement a strategy to promote and expand their participation in the political and economic life of their country.Iraq Women's Fund Act - Directs the Administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) to establish a fund to assist women and girls in Iraq in areas of political, legal, and human rights, health care, education, training, security, and shelter. Authorizes appropriations. Requires funds to be used to support: (1) direct financial and programmatic assistance to the iraq ministry of women's affairs to promote the strengthening of such ministry as the government of Iraq continues its transition to a long-term government structure; and (2) multi-year women-centered economic development programs, including projects to assist widows, female heads of household, women in rural areas, and disabled women.Directs the U.S Agency for International Development (USAID) to provide at least 15% of the aggregate amount of economic and humanitarian assistance authorized for Iraq each of the fiscal years 2006 through 2009 to iraq to support programs and projects for the prevention, control, and prevention of trafficking in persons, trafficking in women and children, and gender-motivated violence, including domestic violence.Iraqi Women's Participation Act - Requires a specified percentage of the economic and humanitarian assistance to be made available directly to iraqi-led local nongovernmental organizations, including iraQi women-led organizations, in each of FY2010-FY2011.Requires the Secretary of State to encourage U.S. organizations that receive funds under this Act to partner with or create iraqi- led counterpart organizations and to provide such organizations with significant financial resources, technical assistance, and capacity building. Requires such entities to provide long-term financial assistance for education for iraQ girls, women, boys, and men. Directs the Secretary to encourage the appointment of women to high level positions within iraraq ministries.Directs the President to ensure that training content and materials are adequate, appropriate, and comprehensive to ensure the implementation of women's rights in Iraq. Requires the President, annually, to transmit to Congress a report on U.S. activities to guarantee the rights of women in Iraq, including progress in implementing this Act and on the status of Women's Rights In Iraq.

predicted_summary.wugwATSS-billsum(on-un: (This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 13, 2014. (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require voice service providers to block certain calls originating from a subscriber to a voice service user using resources from the North American numbering plan. (Sec, in general, the bill defines: "voice service" as any service that furnishes voice services using resources to an end user using a North American telecommunications system or any successor plan adopted by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to connect voice calls made using the resources of the North Americans numbering plan to a subscriber's telephone service.) The bill also prohibits a state or local government from: (1) imposing a charge or fee for the provision of voice service to any subscriber; or (2) requiring a voice services subscriber to purchase, or to transfer, any individual's personal information or credit card number or other personal information.Requires a provider of voice service to offer each subscriber the option to designate, if technically feasible, each telephone number (including a toll-free number) on the subscriber's list for which calls are to be made directly to the subscriber. Directs the subscriber to make such designated numbers available for all incoming calls, without the subscriber being required to connect any such calls through a separate telephone number or to establish a separate account for the call. Provides that: (1) a subscriber to a voice service shall have the right to designate the telephone numbers of such subscriber to receive calls; and (2) the provider shall ensure that any calls to a subscriber are processed according to such preferences.Prohibits a telecommunications carrier or IP-enabled voice service provider from charging a subscriber any fee for the provision of ten free telephone numbers. Requires such providers, in order to be considered to have provided such a service, to allow a subscriber to designate at least ten telephone numbers to be available to the subscriber without charge.Phone Scam Prevention Act of 2014 - Directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to develop authentication standards for providers of a voice service to validate the calling party's number and caller identification information so that subscribers may obtain a secure assurance of the call's origin, including the call number, calling party number, and identification information. Requires providers of voice services that use telephone numbers allocated under the North American numbering plan to adopt the authentication standards developed under this Act.Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to prohibit a Federal Communications Commission (FCC) administrative officer from providing any caller information (including a text message sent using a text messaging service) without the caller's consent. (Currently, such an administrative officer is authorized only to provide caller information regarding a telephone number or a toll-free telephone number.) Requires: (1) the FCC to establish regulations to ensure compliance with such prohibition; and (2) each State to enforce such prohibition.Requires providers of text messaging services to: (1) provide the recipient with appropriate information regarding the recipient's request to send a text message; (2) ensure that the text message is sent only to those individuals who have authorized text message services; (3) provide the sender with a means to verify their request to not be sent; (4) have no charge for sending text messages; (5) provide a method for the verification of text messages to ensure compliance with this Act; (6) establish a process to verify the identity of the recipient of each text message sent using a text messaging service; and (7) provide the same type of information regarding all text messages sent by the same provider to the same or another user.Directs the FCC to prescribe regulations implementing such amendments. Prohibits a person from being in violation of such rules if: (1) the person is a subscriber to any calls made by a subscriber; or (2) the subscriber is the same person as the person who has received such calls. Requires such regulations to prohibit a subscriber who is not a subscriber of any call or text message from being included in such call or message.
predicted_summary.wugNATSS-billsum(on-un: Phone Scam Prevention Act of 2014 - Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to require the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to prescribe regulations to: (1) prohibit any person from using telecommunications services provided by a pay-per-call (P-call) service to obtain personal or financial information, including credit or account information, without the authorization of the subscriber or any authorized person; and (2) require any voice service provider that allows calls originating from a P-call subscriber to connect directly to a subscriber's voice service. Defines "voice service" as any service that furnishes voice communications using resources from the North American Communications Plan (NAC) or any successor plan adopted by the FCC to allow calls to be made using communications resources from a subscriber to an end user using any telecommunications service.Requires a provider of voice service to: (1) offer each subscriber the option to designate non-approved telephone numbers; and (2) ensure that any call the provider receives for termination that is not associated with the subscriber or the telephone number of an entity is processed according to the subscriber's preferences, including by limiting or disabling the ability of an incoming call to connect with a cpe of the subscriber.Requires a provider of a voice service to allow a designated subscriber (or representative of such subscriber) to designate at least ten telephone numbers, free of charge.Directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to develop authentication standards for providers of a voice service so that subscribers may obtain: (1) a secure assurance of the call's origin, including the calling party's name and number, and caller identification information; and (2) notice that such authentication is unavailable. Requires providers of voice services that allocated telephone numbers from the portion of the North American numbering plan that pertains to the United States to adopt the authentication standards developed under this Act. Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to expand the prohibition against the inaccurate disclosure of caller identification or other information to include communications and information between telecommunications and other services.Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to replace provisions regarding the use of text messaging services by the definition of "voice service" with provisions relating to the service of text messages, including a text message sent using a text messaging service.Directs the FCC to prescribe regulations to implement the amendments made by this Act, including to the rules and orders adopted in connection with the application of such amendments.

predicted_summary.wugwATSS-billsum(on-un: This bill prohibits the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) from issuing an export license to a person or entity that: (1) engages in activities that threaten the peace, security, or stability of the country or region; or (2) is a member of the Russian Federation or any other entity that is engaged in any such activities. The Department of State shall prohibit the issuance to a foreign country of a license for the export or reexport of goods, technology, or services to such country or entity if, within one year after the date of the enactment of this bill, such country (or entity) has been determined to have been engaged in an act that jeopardizes the security of: (1) the countries or regions in which such countries or entities are located, or (2) the Ukraine and Russia. The State Department shall, if necessary, prohibit the export to a country or entities of any item on the list of prohibited items.This bill prohibits the sale or transfer to Iran of certain defense articles or services, or the export of any item on which the United States would be prohibited under the export or transfer prohibitions apply. This bill also prohibits the U.S., or any other country or international organization, from providing or transferring to Iran or other countries (or, to the extent that such provision or transfer is not prohibited, making available such assistance or assistance) any export of goods, technology, or services (or any combination of such items) that would be required under the Export Control Act (except as assistance provided in accordance with specified requirements of the Arms Export Act).. (Sec. 4) This bill expresses the sense of the United States that: (1) Iran should be condemned for violating the United Nations Security Council Resolution 2216 and other international obligations; and (2) all countries should implement and enforce sanctions against Iran in accordance with such resolution. (Sec: (1) to prevent Iran from developing nuclear and biological weapons and ballistic missiles and destabilizing weapons, (2) to prevent countries from engaging in acts of international terrorism, and (3) to ensure that such sanctions do not impede the ability of other countries to enforce international agreements against Iran and are implemented by the government of Iran. (2) the President should determine within 45 days whether iranian persons are responsible for blocking the property of persons threatening the peace, security, or the stability of the Middle East and determine whether such persons are in violation of the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996 (which is the same bill as the Iran Threat Reduction Act of 2013). (Sec). The President may waive the application of sanctions under this Act for up to six months if the President determines that it is in the national security interest to do so and the waiver is consistent with the objectives of this Act.Directs the President to submit to Congress a list of iranian persons that the President determines are responsible for engaging in acts of terrorism or related activities in the United States or its territories and possessions. Prohibits such persons from entering into or entering into any contracts or other transactions with any iranIAN person.Requires the President to impose specified sanctions against any person identified in the report submitted to the appropriate congressional committees as having: (1) engaged in activities that undermine international peace and security or that provide support for acts of international terrorism; and (2) knowingly transferred or made funds to, or engaged in transactions on behalf of, any identified foreign person. Sets forth specified mandatory sanctions against persons who knowingly violate the requirements of this Act. (Sec. 6) Directs the President, within 120 days after enactment of this bill, to: (1) impose sanctions against certain foreign entities that have been identified by the Department of the Treasury and the Secretary of State as having provided material support to Iran or terrorist organizations, and (2) prohibit the importation into the United States of any goods, services, or technology from such entities and from providing any other foreign assistance. Authorizes appropriations for FY2017-FY2018 to carry out this bill.Applies such sanctions to: (1) knowingly provide material or technological support for such acts; (2) pursuant to an executive order or pursuant to a United Nations Security Council resolution, a person that violates a specified prohibition against financial support for acts of international terrorism; or (3) an iranian person identified in a specified congressional report. Directs the President to exercise all necessary powers to block and prohibit transactions in property interests of such identified persons and to impose specified sanctions against such persons that knowingly provide such financial or financial support. Requires the President, if he determines that such sanctions are necessary to protect U.S. interests, to direct the Secretary of the Treasury to impose sanctions against the owner or controlled entity of such property.Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to prohibit the issuance of any visa or other documentation to an alien who is a nonimmigrant alien who: (1) is ineligible to receive a U-visa or to receive any benefit under the immigration and nationality Act; and (2) is, or has been, admitted into the United States without authorization or authorization. Sets forth penalties for such violation, including: (1) visa revocation; (2) denial of admission; and (3) paroled entry.Provides that penalties for violations of this Act shall not apply to an alien if the alien is necessary to permit the United States to comply with the agreement regarding the headquarters of the United Nations (or other applicable international obligations) or to comply in any way with the terms of such agreement. Provides that: (1) penalties provided for violations shall apply to persons that knowingly violate, attempt to violate, conspires to violation, or causes such a violation to occur; and (2) such violation shall be considered to be a violation of the prohibition against illegal aliens.Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to prohibit the admission into the United States of any alien who: (1) is an immediate family member of an alien who is a senior member of a terrorist organization, or who otherwise poses a threat to human security; (2) is an individual who has received training in terrorism or terrorist activities; (3) has been convicted of an offense involving terrorism; or (4) is the subject of an order issued by the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) or any other federal agency that prohibits the entry of aliens into the U.S.., or any of its territories or possessions. Authorizes the President to impose sanctions for violations of such prohibitions.Prohibits the U.S. Government from issuing any visa to, or entry into the United States of, any alien who: (1) is a member of a specified entity designated by the United Nations (U.N.) Security Council or any other international organization, or (2) is a senior official of such entity or entity.Requires the President, every five years, to report to Congress regarding: (1) the U.S. government's involvement in terrorist activities; and (2) the activities of foreign governments and organizations to which the United States is a party.Authorizes the President to impose sanctions in order to protect U.S. national security interests. Directs the United States Permanent Representative to the United Nations (UN) to submit a report to the appropriate congressional committees recommending such sanctions.
predicted_summary.wugNATSS-billsum(on-un: This bill requires the President to submit to Congress a report assessing the effectiveness of the sanctions imposed on Iran and other countries in preventing the spread of weapons of mass destruction and terrorism, supporting terrorism, and supporting acts of international terrorism. ( with U or of the Federal and of the Government of the Secretary of the effects on such.Directs the President to impose specified sanctions against such Iranian persons and entities if the President determines that such activities pose a threat to the United States national security.Directs the President to impose certain executive order sanctions against entities that knowingly and materially support or provide financial, material, or technological support for acts that violate the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996, the Iran-United Nations Security Council Resolution, or any other applicable international law. Requires such sanctions to be imposed pursuant to such an executive order, if the President determines that such action constitutes a violation of such international law and submits to Congress a report identifying: (1) the person or entity involved; (2) the person and such entity that is owned or controlled by such person.Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to eliminate the nonimmigrant visa waiver program for certain foreign nationals who are determined to be ineligible for permanent residence or employment in the United States or to otherwise benefit from such waiver.Sets forth penalties for violations of this Act, including the establishment of penalties for the illegal entry or entry into the United States of aliens who commit such violations or who knowingly attempt to do so.Authorizes the President to exercise all authorities provided to the President under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and to promulgate regulations necessary for the implementation of this Act.Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit any person from entering or maintaining a residence or business in the United States or its territories with the intent to: (1) promote or encourage investment or business activities, or to acquire or increase investment interests, if the person is a foreign person; (2) engage in any activities that may adversely affect foreign policy or international relations, or that have an effect on U.S. foreign policy, unless the Secretary of State (Secretary) certifies to the appropriate congressional committees that the person does not have, or will have, any adverse effect on such conduct. (Sec. 4) Sets forth criminal and civil penalties for violations of this Act.Requires the President to report to Congress on Iranian activities in Iran for a period of five years and every 180 days for five years to describe Iranian support for certain terrorist groups, including weapons of mass destruction and funding, financing, training, and political violence.Amends the Housing and Community Development Act to authorize appropriations: (1) for the Department of Housing and Urban Development; (2) the Federal National Mortgage Association; (3) the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation; and (4) the Federal Housing Administration.
